docs.title: Contributing
docs.description: Use the _Edit this page_ button at the bottom of each page.  This will lead you to the source `md` file.

docs.title:
Documentation for
SAP Cloud Application Programming Model
Hybrid Testing { #hybrid-testing}
docs.description: CAP enables you to run and test your CAP application using a local SQLite database and mocks to a large extent. However, you might want to test with actual cloud services at some point.

docs.title: Advanced Topics and Concepts
docs.description: This section provides information on advanced topics and concepts that are not covered in the cookbook guides.

docs.title: Getting Started in a Nutshell
docs.description: Build Your First App with CAP {.subtitle}

docs.title: Aspect-Oriented Modeling
docs.description: The technique of [*Aspects*](cdl#aspects) provides a very powerful means to organize your models in a way that keeps your core domain models concise and comprehensible by factoring out secondary concerns into separate files, defining and reusing common aspects, as well as adapting reused definitions to specific needs.

docs.title: Conceptual Definition Language (CDL)
docs.description: The *Conceptual Definition Language (CDL)* is a human-readable language for defining CDS models. Sources are commonly provided in files with`.cds` extensions and get compiled into [CSN representations](csn). Following sections provide a reference of all language constructs in CDL, which also serves as a reference of all corresponding CDS concepts and features.

docs.title: Query Language (CQL)
docs.description: CDS Query Language (CQL) is based on standard SQL, which it enhances by...

docs.title: Expression Notation (CXN) { #expressions}
docs.description: Expressions in CDS definitions and queries can be one of:

docs.title: Core / Built-in Types
docs.description: The following table lists the built-in types available to all CDS models, and can be used to define entity elements or custom types as follows:

docs.title: Using H2 for Development in CAP Java
docs.description: For local development and testing, CAP Java supports the [H2](https://www.h2database.com/) database, which can be configured to run in-memory.

docs.title: Using SAP HANA Cloud for Production
Using SQLite for Development {#sqlite}
docs.description: CAP provides extensive support for [SQLite](https://www.sqlite.org/index.html), which allows projects to speed up development by magnitudes at minimized costs. We strongly recommend using this option as much as possible during development and testing.

docs.title: Using Databases
docs.description: <!-- REVISIT: Didn't we say no synopsis any more, but toc straight away? -->

docs.title: Domain Modeling
docs.description: Domain Models capture the static, data-related aspects of a problem domain in terms of entity-relationship models. They serve as the basis for *[persistence models](./databases)* deployed to databases as well as for *[service definitions](./providing-services)*.

docs.title: The CAP Cookbook
docs.description: Guides and Recipes for Common Tasks

docs.title: Authentication
docs.description: {{$frontmatter?.synopsis}} This is done by [authentication middlewares](#strategies) setting the [`cds.context.user` property](#cds-user) which is then used in [authorization enforcement](#enforcement) decisions.

docs.title: Best Practices
docs.description: From generic Node.js best practices like dependency management and error handling to CAP-specific topics like transaction handling and testing, this [video](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=WTOOse-Flj8&t=87s) provides some tips and tricks to improve the developer experience and avoid common pitfalls, based on common customer issues. In the following section we explain these best practices.

docs.title: Connecting to Required Services
docs.description: Services frequently consume other services, which could be **local** services served by the same process, or **external** services, for example consumed through OData.

docs.title: The *cds* FaÃ§ade Object {#title}
docs.description: The `cds` facade object provides access to all CAP Node.js APIs. Use it like that:

docs.title: CDS Plugin Packages
docs.description: The `cds-plugin` technique allows to provide extension packages with auto-configuration.

docs.title: Bootstrapping Servers
docs.description: CAP Node.js servers are bootstrapped through a [built-in `server.js` module](#built-in-server-js), which can be accessed through [`cds.server`](#cds-server). You can plug-in custom logic to the default bootstrapping choreography using a [custom `server.js`](#custom-server-js) in your project.

docs.title: Transaction Management
docs.description: Transaction management in CAP deals with (ACID) database transactions, principal / context propagation on service-to-service calls and tenant isolation.

docs.title: Fiori Support
docs.description: See [Cookbook > Serving UIs > Draft Support](../advanced/fiori#draft-support) for an overview on SAP Fiori Draft support in CAP.

docs.title: Remote Services <Concept />
docs.description: Class `cds.RemoteService` is a service proxy class to consume remote services via different [protocols](/node.js/cds-serve#cds-protocols), like OData or plain REST.

docs.title: Using TypeScript
docs.description: While CAP itself is written in _JavaScript_, it's possible to use _TypeScript_ within your project as outlined here.

docs.title: CAP Plugins & Enhancements
docs.description: Following is a curated list of plugins that are available for the SAP Cloud Application Programming Model (CAP) which provide integration with SAP BTP services and technologies, or other SAP products.

docs.title: CDS Typer {#cds-typer}
docs.description: The following chapter describes the [`cds-typer` package](https://www.npmjs.com/package/@cap-js/cds-typer) in detail using the [bookshop sample](https://github.com/SAP-samples/cloud-cap-samples/tree/main/bookshop) as a running example.

docs.title: Publishing to OpenAPI
docs.description: You can convert CDS models to the [OpenAPI Specification](https://www.openapis.org), a widely adopted API description standard.

docs.title: Moving From _.hdbcds_ To _.hdbtable_
docs.description: ::: info Not relevant for SAP HANA Cloud

docs.title: Upgrade to Compiler v2
docs.description: <!-- Keep this page, as _many_ links point to it! -->

docs.title: Using SAP Cloud Application Event Hub in Cloud Foundry
docs.description: [SAP Cloud Application Event Hub](https://help.sap.com/docs/event-broker) is the new default offering for messaging in SAP Business Technology Platform (SAP BTP).

docs.title: Using SAP Event Mesh in Cloud Foundry
docs.description: CAP provides out-of-the-box support for [SAP Event Mesh](https://help.sap.com/docs/event-mesh), and automatically handles many things behind the scenes, so that application coding stays agnostic and focused on conceptual messaging.

docs.title: Receiving Events from SAP S/4HANA Cloud Systems
docs.description: SAP S/4HANA integrates SAP Event Mesh as well as SAP Cloud Application Event Hub for messaging.

docs.title: Task Queues
docs.description: The _Outbox Pattern_ is a reliable strategy used in distributed systems to ensure that messages or events are consistently recorded and delivered, even in the face of failures.

docs.title: Health Checks
docs.description: On both Cloud Foundry and Kubernetes, it is possible to provide two separate endpoints for liveness checks ("are you alive?") and readiness checks ("are you ready for more requests?").

docs.title: Microservices with CAP
docs.description: A comprehensive guide on deploying your CAP application as microservices.

docs.title: Audit Logging
docs.description: The  [`@cap-js/audit-logging`](https://www.npmjs.com/package/@cap-js/audit-logging) plugin provides out-of-the box support for automatic audit logging of data privacy-related events, in particular changes to *personal data* and reads of *sensitive* data. Find here a step-by-step guide how to use it.
